node.title: A private-tutor matching service is growing fast with zero investor funding
node.content:
There’s a reason why adults still have nightmares about going back to school. All the hours spent burning the midnight oil have left indelible scars on our subconscious. So when Nicolas Vanhove founded Tutoroo, a startup that matches learners to private tutors specializing in language, he wanted the service to be affordable, convenient, and, most of all, a social experience.

If you’ve ever used a home-sharing service like Airbnb, Tutoroo is basically cut from the same cloth. On Tutoroo’s website, you enter the language you want to learn, your preferred time to take lessons, as well as your current location. In turn, Tutoroo will present a list of private tutors nearby who fit the bill.

Once a tutor has been selected, Tutoroo will contact the student via WhatsApp, and private sessions – usually done in public places – will be set up soon after. There’s a wide variety of languages to choose from, with 64,000 available tutors worldwide, offering languages from English, Japanese and French to Urdu, Xhosa, and sign language.

Once you input your preferences, Tutoroo will show you a list of available tutors nearby.

In 2007, Vanhove moved from France to Montreal, Canada, to study at a business school. Just before he graduated in 2010, he was offered a marketing position in a startup. Seeing how a startup machine operated from the inside was an eye-opening experience for the fresh graduate.

Vanhove then began to have ideas of his own, the first of which came to fruition when he moved to Hong Kong in 2013. There, he launched a website called Get the Deal Now, which connected users to cheap, last-minute deals and promotions in the area. To make ends meet in the notoriously expensive city, Vanhove also taught private French-language lessons on the side to eager local students.

Tutoroo founder Nicolas Vanhove

Soon, he found himself pocketing about US$6,390 a month from his side gig. For a 26-year-old living in Hong Kong at the time, it was enough for a decent living. In fact, he continued to tutor Hong Kong-based students in French via Skype even after moving to Singapore in 2014. Working five-hour days wasn’t a bad deal at all, but things soon got out of hand when more Hong Kong students hired him. Vanhove could no longer keep up.

“Then my friend had a brilliant idea. He asked me, ‘Why don’t you match [these students] to native French speakers in Hong Kong, and you take a transaction fee for every match you make?’ So that’s exactly what I have done,” Vanhove explains.

No tests, no homework – just conversations

Tutoroo started in 2016 with only two cities on the map: Hong Kong and Singapore. Within two short years, however, it has expanded to 19 cities, including Dubai, Sydney, Cape Town, Manila, Jakarta, and Tel Aviv. The startup has also generated over US$731,000 in revenue – not bad for a completely bootstrapped company with zero funding.

While Vanhove firmly believes that just about any native language speaker can be a private tutor, Tutoroo still does extensive screenings and interviews beforehand. For students who want professional language tutors, however, Tutoroo will also link them up – at a steeper price, of course.

Speaking of price, one of Tutoroo’s chief goals is to make learning language as affordable as possible. According to Vanhove, Alliance Française, a non-profit French school and Tutoroo competitor, charges about US$130 per hour. A quick search for French tutors in Singapore on Tutoroo, on the other hand, brought up competitive rates at no more than US$43.83 per hour. “You do the math!” he exclaims.

On Tutoroo, once a match has been established between a student and a tutor, its customer relationship management system will kick in. Every match is tracked, and Tutoroo takes 100 percent of the first two weeks of tutoring fees – a tried-and-true revenue model for traditional tuition agencies. Every subsequent payment goes to the tutor directly.

A backend look at how Tutoroo tracks each individual transaction from multiple cities

Lessons on Tutoroo are flexible. Students pay by the hour, so they can stop at any time. Also, since they are usually conducted by ordinary people, there are no tests to be taken or no homework to be handed in. Tutoroo’s tutors engage students in a natural conversation that also teaches them to speak a foreign language.

Start small, go (very) big

Vanhove has big dreams for the road ahead. For one, he wants to provide resources for tutors “to help them organize and structure their lessons better.” Also, plans are in the works to shift from a transaction-based service to a subscription-based one. The details are still forthcoming, but the team is hard at work, according to Vanhove.

Chief among his goals, however, is expansion. Vanhove wants Tutoroo to be in 100 cities by the end of 2020. The startup is now raising a round of funding to help make that happen.

“We are about to make US$511,366 in revenue this year – that’s compared to US$262,988 last year. That’s a 7 percent month-on-month growth. We [want to] shift from that to US$25.6 million by end of 2021.”

This goal is significant, considering that Tutoroo only has a team of 18 – based in Singapore, Indonesia, and the Philippines – and much of its business is still conducted manually over WhatsApp.

To the casual bystander, the last point may sound unscalable in the long run. Vanhove, however, is not quite ready to do away with a tried-and-tested method just yet. “I believe that entrepreneurs should experiment with things [and] see what works and what doesn’t,” he explains.

“Brian Rothenberg, vice president and general manager of Eventbrite, is a big inspiration for me. He taught me that sometimes we need to do a lot of things that don’t scale in order to build traction and achieve the things that do scale. Right now, we have a recipe that works [in 19 cities], and I don’t see anything that will stop us from duplicating it in 100 other cities.”

Currency converted from Singapore dollars. US$1 = S$1.37.

node.title: Why the Philippines may be Grab and Go-Jek’s most challenging market
node.content:
Photo credit: Go-Jek.

In May, Go-Jek announced that it would enter four Southeast Asian markets within 2018, giving Grab’s monopoly some serious competition. The countries on the Indonesian company’s list included Vietnam, Thailand, Singapore, and the Philippines.

So far, it has expanded to all except the Philippines, where ride-hailing revenue is expected to increase by 30 percent annually. One in five people in the capital Manila rely on ride-hailing services, nearly double what’s seen in other cities in the region.

So what’s stopping Go-Jek from rolling out in the archipelago?

Thwarted application

The biggest hurdle for the Indonesian firm is a regulatory one.

In August, the Philippines’ Land Transportation Franchising and Regulatory Board (LTFRB) issued a circular suspending new license applications for transport network companies (TNCs).

The suspension meant that new players like Go-Jek wouldn’t be able to apply to operate legally in the country. The ruling came after the LTFRB saw an influx of TNC applications when it lifted a previous ban on applications for transport network vehicle services (TNVS).

While Go-Jek did submit its application on August 13, the circular was signed and ordered by the board on August 9. “The moratorium came out before [Go-Jek] filed their application for accreditation,” said LTFRB chairman Martin Delgra III in a media statement last September.

“[The company’s application] is still pending. We’re still reviewing it,” Delgra told Tech in Asia in an interview.

The LTFRB also implemented a cap on the number of TNVS – ride-hailing vehicles that are allowed to ply the streets – at 65,000 units.

According to Delgra, they’re not looking to lift the ban on new TNC license applications yet because of this cap.

“Right now, there is no basis to increase the 65,000 to 80,000 or 100,000. Once we are able to hit the 65,000, we’ll see whether there is stiff competition – if it’s no longer healthy or that there’s still room for a few more TNCs,” Delgra says.

However, ride-hailing firms like Grab have aggressively lobbied to increase the 65,000 cap.

“More passengers are waiting for longer hours and, worse, getting stranded on the road because they could not get a ride,” a Grab spokesperson says, noting that Grab and Uber had 125,000 units operating in the country before the cap.

Considering Go-Jek itself has over 400,000 drivers for its motorbike-hailing service in Indonesia and wants to serve “hundreds of thousands” of users in Singapore, having to share 65,000 units in the Philippines with several other firms does not even come close.

Eight homegrown firms are currently accredited as TNCs in the Philippines: Hype, GoLag, iPara, Hirna, Micab, E-Pick Up, Aztech Solution, and Ryd Global. Grab and local firm U-Hop’s applications are still up for renewal.

Grab’s struggles

If not lifted soon, the supply cap is another issue that Go-Jek will have to contend with if it’s able to enter the Philippine market.

A Grab spokesperson said that the Philippines has been their least-performing market in Southeast Asia, despite the Singapore-based company having a virtual monopoly.

According to Grab, the number of TNVS allowed to operate is nowhere near enough. The company’s allocation rate dropped to 40 percent after the cap was enforced.

Grab’s allocation rate drops after the 65,000 cap was imposed. / Photo credit: Grab

However, the startup says there has been no decline in demand. It’s now relying on its GrabShare feature to cope with the supply issue, along with submitting proposals to LTFRB to increase the supply cap to 80,500.

While Grab country head Brian Cu sees the Philippines as an important piece of the ride-hailer’s portfolio, he says that “overregulation” has stifled its earnings and growth.

The company had to implement subsidies amid slowing earnings for its drivers. It was also fined Php 10 million (US$188,000) for violating terms of its acquisition deal with Uber and Php 12 million (US$226,000) for allegedly overcharging its customers with an extra Php 2-per-minute charge without first consulting the LTFRB. The board later allowed the company to charge the extra amount but maintained the fine.

Cu points out that the company has already incurred Php 4.5 billion (roughly US$85 million) in losses since it entered the Philippines. Despite this, however, he says Grab still plans to inject Php 3 billion (US$56 million) to grow the market. A Business Mirror report predicts Grab’s losses will soar to Php 7.5 billion (US$141 million) by 2020 if existing regulations persist.

Restrictions on private motorcycles

Go-Jek is known for motorbike-hailing in Indonesia, and it also offers the service in its newer markets Thailand and Vietnam. So another potential challenge it may face in the Philippines is a recent court ruling barring motorcycles from ferrying passengers around.

Local motorbike-hailer Angkas was forced to cease operations on December 12 after the Supreme Court issued a temporary restraining order (TRO) on an earlier ruling that the startup could operate in the country. The basis of the TRO, according to Delgra, is section 7 of Republic Act No. 4136, which states that motorbikes are not allowed to ferry customers for profit. The same rule also restricts “private passenger automobiles” from doing the same. Yet, Grab and other ride-hailing firms are allowed to operate all over the country.

Delgra maintains that LTFRB is only following the Supreme Court’s decision to stop Angkas from operations until the legality of its service can be verified. “They are supposed to stop. As to the legality of their business, that is the question mark,” he explains.

For now, the LTFRB is bound to arrest any Angkas driver caught operating on the streets.

While this may somewhat limit Go-Jek’s opportunities in the Philippines, it may not be that big of a problem. In Singapore, for example, the startup launched its beta app with a car-hailing feature but not motorbike-hailing. It also has several other services under its belt, which Go-Jek CEO Nadiem Makarim says are more profitable than its transportation businesses, anyway.

Go-Jek can also strategize its Philippine entry with other services like food delivery, which is a growing segment in the country. However, it will no doubt face tough competitors like Grab which are already entrenched in the market.

Go-Jek’s options

Statista data shows that revenue in the Philippines’ ride-hailing segment amounted to US$498 million in 2018. It is also expected to grow by 30 percent annually, compared to 20 percent for Indonesia and 8.5 percent in Singapore.

This means that Go-Jek stands to gain a lot once it enters the country.

Bloomberg reported in September that the Indonesian giant was aiming to raise at least US$2 billion, which it will use to bankroll its Southeast Asia expansion. This comes on top of the US$1.5 billion it raised in February to compete against Grab.

Currency converted from Philippine peso. US$1 = P52.9

node.title: A brief history of China’s biggest tech booms and busts
node.content:
China’s tech industry has been growing for so long that the ongoing crisis involving Ofo and other bike-share startups is far from the first boom and bust for an entire sector. Here are some of the biggest flare-ups and flame-outs over the years:

2009 to 2013: Daily deals

While Groupon-esque daily deals are still a thing on China’s internet, the scene is dominated by a small handful of apps, with literally thousands – yes, thousands – of earlier rivals having died out.

The craze began in China around 2009, a year after Groupon was born, as local entrepreneurs latched onto restaurant and shopping deals as a way to tackle Alibaba’s dominance in online shopping.

Photo credit: ygai / 123RF

At the height of daily deals mania toward the end of 2011, China had 5,000 competing sites.

One such site was a total rip-off of Groupon called Groupon.cn that quickly grew to 4,000 employees – mainly hastily hired salespeople spread across the country to lure stores into listing deals on its website. By late 2011, Groupon.cn had fired all but 700 of its staffers. By late 2012, the startup was dead.

A study that year found 2,082 deals sites had shut down in the space of nine months.

By early 2013, 90 percent of China’s daily deals were bought on just 10 sites, leaving everyone else to fight over the scraps.

In many ways, China’s daily deals space is a blueprint for how Chinese entrepreneurs like to rush into a new opportunity that has low barriers, throwing relatively cheap resources (such as labor) to inflate the business as quickly as humanly possible. Then the unsustainable rush peters down to just a few surviving services.

2012 to 2016: Smartphones

In 2014, China had around 500 smartphone makers – but that dropped to 100 two years later.

Dead and gone: smartphone maker Gionee / Photo credit: Gionee

And that eventually would fall further as China’s top four homegrown smartphone brands – Huawei, Vivo, Oppo, and Xiaomi – squeezed smaller brands into an ever tinier margin over the past few years.

The slowdown happened at home as well as in important overseas markets such as India.

2014 to 2018: Peer-to-peer lending

A similar free-for-all as the daily deals farrago happened later when peer-to-peer lending became the hot new thing.

Taking money from lenders desperate for high interest rates proved to be as easy as stealing candy from children – and fraudulent sites showed that the stealing part was simple as well.

Photo credit: DC Master

Thousands of startups soon popped up.

The promises of high returns and straightforward loans soured in 2017 amid a series of bankruptcies and outright scams, such as one firm that turned out to be a US$7.6 billion Ponzi scheme.

Hundreds of lenders collapsed in early 2018, leaving some to risk protesting on the streets in the hopes that their money would be returned.

While P2P lending persists, with a few big-name sites such as Dianrong and Yirendai having launched IPOs in a bid to win public trust, 80 percent of the 6,200 loans startups in China have now either closed or fallen into crisis, according to a study cited by Bloomberg.

2016 to ?: Bike-sharing

The bike-sharing blowout isn’t over yet, but it’s a prime exemple of the entrepreneurial and venture capital hubris that means these booms and busts will keep on going in a – pardon the pun – cyclical fashion.

Photo credit: luoxi / 123RF

Bike-sharing gained momentum across China in 2016 as an alternative to ride-hailing for short journeys. A fast-rising wave of startups doing the exact same thing resulted in bicycles clogging up city streets, and eventually forming bike graveyards as municipalities seized the two-wheelers.

By 2017, smaller startups were already dying out as a pair of medium-sized rivals joined forces in holy merger-y.

Around 60 bike-share startups crashed and burned in one 18-month window, and many went down with users’ deposits.

This week, Ofo – one of the top two bike apps – admitted that it was considering bankruptcy as it juggled three bombs: huge losses, dwindling cash, and fleeing users demanding their deposits back.

“It now appears bike sharing is the stupidest business, but the smartest brains of China all tried to get in,” the founder of bankrupt startup 3Vbike said to Reuters recently. “It really now seems ridiculous.”

node.title: Startups are realigning Singapore’s dental industry
node.content:
In a world where industries are innovating at a breakneck pace, Singapore’s dental market has been slow to catch on. Some players, however, are looking to change the game.

Lumiere32 is one. Raman Chauhan, a co-founder of the dental supplies platform, laments that door-to-door representatives still pitch products to dentists, a rather archaic method considering that everyone shops online these days.

Photo credit: Unsplash

Digital and social media platforms influence buying decisions, strengthen a brand, and expand a product’s digital footprint, he says.

“Imagine you are a dentist browsing through an article online and you saw a dental product ad. You simply click on that ad, which directs you to the site of the product, and make an inquiry,” says Chauhan. “That’s how you win new customers and generate better-qualified leads, rather than employing sales reps who wait nearly an hour at the clinic just to speak about a product for only a few minutes.”

Distribution channels for medical products and supplies are still heavily fragmented, according to Chauhan.

The sales rep model has been successful for 30 years, and they are still important when it comes to explaining the intricacies of new technologies such as computer-assisted design (CAD) and 3D imaging and printing, he says.

But there are still some inefficiencies that could be addressed with technology. The key to solving this issue is to provide a one-stop digital platform for dental supplies.

Targeting Southeast Asia and India, Lumiere32 was founded in early 2016 by Priti Bhole, who is a dentist by profession. Chauhan is bringing to the table six years of market research and IT strategy consulting experience with tech clients such as Cisco, IBM, and Microsoft.

Lumiere32 currently has 650 registered dental clinics, with more than half of the clinics located in Singapore.

It is also supported by NUS Enterprise, the incubator arm of the National University of Singapore. To date, the startup has secured S$350,000 (US$255,269) in funding and is looking to close another S$600,000 (US$437,604) by February next year.

Reducing inpatient costs and visits

Julian Artopé, founder and CEO of Zenyum, a startup that customizes and manufactures transparent dental aligners, claims his company is now the biggest distributor of dental aligners in Singapore.

Zenyum’s aligners cost a third of conventional invisible aligners, which can range from S$6,000 (US$4,376) to S$8,000 (US$5,834). However, its aligners can only treat mild to moderate cases.

“We are able to drive patients at scale because of our marketing platforms: mainly Instagram, Facebook, and obviously, Google,” he says.

A dental aligner from Zenyum / Photo credit: Zenyum

Reducing patient visitations and discomfort are key to Zenyum’s business. For instance, its main competitor Invisalign requires inpatient consultations every two to three months.

For Zenyum, clients send pictures of their teeth every two weeks through an app so dentists can check on progress and teeth movement, as well as to make new aligners in advance. This is especially useful for patients who dislike visiting the dentist.

“The standard of care is heightened, but you don’t have to spend time at the [clinic] as much,” he says.

See: Singapore startup straightens your teeth at much lower fees than conventional peers

Zenyum’s partner dentists, who perform side procedures such as cleaning or extractions at a reduced cost so the patient can fully qualify for aligners, use cutting-edge technologies like intra-oral scanners instead of traditional dental impressions.

Scanners are less invasive, more accurate, and won’t make you gag since it eliminates the use of alginate – the gooey substance used in dental trays which are inserted into a patient’s mouth , says Artopé.

The startup, which is only a few months old, has managed to secure investments of an undisclosed amount from local funds and medtech investors. Zenyum also intends to add affordable retainers to its product range soon.

Dental 3D printing

A key innovation for the dental industry has been 3D printers. After receiving the intra-oral scans created by dentists, the printers can churn out customized aligners, casts, dentures, and other dental applications, speeding up turnaround time while lowering manufacturing costs.

Singapore-based Structo, which makes 3D printers for both dental labs and individual dentists, as well as the printers’ “ink” cartridges, claims its patented Mask Stereolithography technology achieves a higher throughput, which translates to a lower manufacturing cost.

Founded in 2014 by engineers Chin Kah Fai, Huub van Esbroeck, Devansh Sharma, and Lam Siu Hon as a generalist 3D printer maker, Structo eventually doubled down on the dental industry.

See: How Structo found its 3D printing niche in the booming dental industry

The startup has sold 100 printers to date worldwide, with North America as its biggest market. Its investors include GGV Capital, Wavemakers, Enterprise Singapore, and some angel investors.

“The single largest user of 3D printers is not in aerospace or prototyping. It is in dentistry,” says Structo’s marketing manager Jonathan Lim. Dentistry is uniquely suited for 3D printers because of the need for customization – each patient’s mouth and jaw are unique.

Structo’s 3D printer / Photo credit: Structo

Structo’s flagship DentaForm printer is capable of printing up to 10 dental arches in 30 minutes. Depending on the technology, other printers can take anywhere between one and four hours for the same throughput, says Lim.

Velox, Structo’s other flagship product, is aimed at individual dentists. It is designed to be easy-to-use for clinicians, says Lim, and is supposedly the world’s first desktop 3D printer that offers a complete workflow from printing and washing to curing (the hardening of the material used in dental appliances).

“Clinicians’ main day-to-day tasks are diagnosing and treating patients. It is a steep learning curve for them to learn 3D printing and CAD or computer-aided manufacturing software. They shouldn’t be wasting time on heavy machinery,” says Lim.

node.title: Go-Jek’s subsidies are a potent tool to gain market share. Keeping it is another matter.
node.content:
The war to become Southeast Asia’s dominant superapp is turning white-hot.

Go-Jek’s launch in Singapore has been controversial as it had allegedly scraped Grab’s map data. Go-Jek did not deny this, and lawyers say that the Indonesian firm may be liable for violating copyright laws.

While data scraping may have sped up Go-Jek’s launch, it has an even more powerful weapon that may turn its underdog status into an advantage.

Illustration: Centaine Lim

Let’s say you’re a new player in a price-sensitive market. The best way to gain market share over a dominant player isn’t ads. It’s promotions and subsidies.

“As a smaller player, you definitely want to subsidize. It makes sense in terms of capital leverage,” says a former Uber executive in Southeast Asia who asked to remain anonymous. “If the other player wants to match your subsidies, they will have to fork out a lot more. It’s a tough spot for the larger player.”

Suppose you give a user a US$5 discount for each ride. You reach 1 million rides in your first month. That amounts to a cost of US$5 million.

Now, let’s say you’re the market leader. You’re doing 50 million rides a month. If you want to match the prices of the new player, you’d need to foot a hefty US$250 million bill.

This is why subsidies are the fire starters that allows upstarts to gain market share quickly and cheaply.

On the flipside, could this be the reason why Grab is steering clear of promos as a means of fending off Go-Jek?

A Grab-branded electric Hyundai Ioniq car / Photo credit: Grab

A person with knowledge of Grab’s plans tells Tech in Asia: “We don’t view subsidies solely through the lens of cost. We ask ourselves, ‘Is it strategic? Will it lead to long-term customer engagement and loyalty?’”

Subsidies have been found to have a fatal flaw: they don’t necessarily lead to repeat users. Instead, Grab is prioritizing ways of adding value to users that would also bring them back again and again to the Grab ecosystem.

The firm has launched subscription plans and a rewards program. It also plans to trial cheaper rides with bigger vehicles and use technology to drive down car maintenance costs.

Pointing to the US, which is a more mature ride-hailing market, the source notes that both Uber and Lyft have reduced their use of subsidies as they prepare for public listings in 2019.

Consumers would be “pissed off” whenever subsidies are withdrawn, so it doesn’t make sense to start another price war, Grab has told the media. It also doesn’t expect its use of subsidies to rise to the level of its previous battle with Uber.

It’s raining subsidies

Yet given the power of promotions in gaining market share, it will still have a role to play in Southeast Asia. This could explain why smaller ride-hailing services like Tada – which has zero commission fees – have been gaining traction in Singapore. It’s likely going to be why Go-Jek will gain on Grab in Southeast Asia – although Grab has publicly stated that short-term fluctuations in market share won’t be a concern.

Promotions aren’t a new tactic, of course. But internet companies have taken them to new heights by collecting data on new users and deploying product hooks to turn them into repeat customers.

For example, Dropbox’s famous refer-a-friend program is a promotional tactic that subsidizes the cost of using the service. Closer to Southeast Asia, Shopee has successfully used shipping subsidies to overtake Lazada and Tokopedia as the top ecommerce marketplace in the region.

It’s even possible that Grab wielded subsidies to overtake Go-Jek in Indonesia. Since 2016, Grab has claimed to have a larger market share of rides in the country than Go-Jek. The latter has declined to respond to the claim.

Subsidies have to be very targeted towards certain behaviors.

Grab will continue using promotions in order to get people to try its new services, such as GrabFood. In Singapore, it dangled vouchers to entice users to sign up for its food-delivery subscription program.

The super app certainly isn’t ending its relationship to subsidies – deploying them makes sense when the goal is to gain market share at low cost or to attract new customers.

Subsidies are also useful for encouraging new behaviors, the former Uber executive says. “Say you have a driver who drives every morning. You can give them a monetary incentive to drive in the evening. That way you can gain incremental driver hours. It wouldn’t make sense to incentivize them to drive in the morning. Subsidies have to be very targeted towards certain behaviors.”

The word “incremental” is key. Subsidies should push the users to use the app in situations where they previously wouldn’t have done so. This increases the stickiness of the service.

Shift in tactics

As long as investors keep pouring money, heavy subsidies will continue to be a feature among internet apps. Promotional campaigns by two well-funded players can prevent a monopoly from happening – a safeguard that should please commuters and regulators for now.

Smaller competitors in Singapore like Tada and Ryde will do their best to keep up with the giants, though they have to avoid fighting a price war eventually and find other ways to add value to users.

As for Go-Jek, it’ll need to use subsidies to continue gaining market share and impress investors in order to raise even more cash. It can’t afford to show signs of weakness or go into a slowdown.

Like Grab, subsidies won’t be its only weapon. “As we look to acquire consumers, driver-partners and merchants, subsidies represent just one of many different mechanisms that we will deploy. This approach helps us provide a truly viable, long-term choice for all of our Southeast Asian markets,” Go-Jek said in a statement to Tech in Asia.

The Uber executive sees Go-Jek shifting gears as it gains market share. Using subsidies to acquire users works up to a point – Go-Jek can reach a 30 to 35 percent share of each market using that tactic, he estimates.

After that, it’s not just about price but also speed and reliability. “If I make a booking on the app, the car needs to come quickly,” he says.

Something to watch out for is how the Indonesian firm performs outside its home turf. It’s off to a good start in Vietnam – Go-Viet has topped the travel category in the app store, though it hasn’t made the same impact in Thailand. App store rankings only provide a partial picture of how the app is performing, however. While Go-Jek might see a short-term growth spurt in market share, Grab’s branding and ubiquity cannot be underestimated.

It goes without saying that Go-Jek will need to out-innovate and out-execute its rival to sustain its goodwill among consumers and merchants. But given how easy it is in the internet space to copy one another, even ingenuity may not be enough.

node.title: Why Singapore’s Smart Nation plan needs a new kind of money to succeed
node.content:
Disclosure: I work at Rate3 Network, a protocol that handles asset tokenization and identity management across Ethereum and Stellar blockchains. I’m also one of the editors of the SGDR blog.

As we grow accustomed to the sight of everyday Singaporean moms and pops tap their phones at their local grocery outlet for payments, one can’t help but marvel at the pace and receptiveness at which our young nation has welcomed innovation in payments with open arms. This is especially resonating, considering the strategic focus which we have detailed toward planning our e-payments infrastructure for the next five years.

Perhaps, this was always ingrained somewhere in our DNA. Lost between the sands of time was the fact that “money” at different points in Singapore’s history meant many different things – from Song dynasty coins in the 14th century, the Indian rupee and the Mexican dollar during the early 19th century, to even a whole smattering of silver dollar coins produced by far-flung nations such as Peru and Bolivia during the later half of the 1800s.

When it comes to how commerce was conducted and payments were settled, traders in early Singapore simply adapted to the circumstances as they unfurled.

How will we – as an aspiring, self-proclaimed “smart nation” –  adapt to the challenges of tomorrow in this regard?

This is where SGDR, a Singapore-dollar denominated, price-stable crypto asset (affectionately termed by the blockchain industry as stablecoin), will have an important role in helping to forge the next chapter of our journey toward being a smart nation.

But what exactly is a smart nation?

While this has been a phrase that has been bandied about regularly, you get the feeling that its definition and objectives have yet to be fully grasped by most Singaporeans – despite it having its own Wikipedia page which says: “Smart Nation is a Singaporean government initiative to harness infocomm technologies, networks, and big data to create tech-enabled solutions.”

Basically, the government wishes to build a high-tech Singapore with the latest technologies leveraging networks and data, which has long been touted to be the new “black gold.”

The initiatives in Smart Nation are meant to ensure that Singapore is well-prepared to leverage on this new macro trend, which capitalizes on data and computing power as basic building blocks. It is clear that the Singaporean government hasn’t simply just paid lip service to this lofty ambition – the meticulous details of the planned initiatives show otherwise.

The key to delivering on the value for many of these initiatives is automation, which itself can only be done if the basic building blocks that make up the task are programmable.

Why would today’s payments infrastructure be incompatible with Smart Nation?

Stablecoins like SGDR helps bring to the masses the benefits of cryptocurrency minus price volatility.

It allows for cheap, fast, and programmable transactions, which in turn will help unlock payment models that are not readily viable with today’s payments infrastructure, such as micropayments and event-driven payments.

To illustrate, fast and ultra-cheap transactions opens up the use case of paying an online video content provider directly without a middleman on a per-hour-watched micropayment basis, rather than on a subscription model.

The minimum per transaction fees, which incumbents charge, prohibits that today. For example, according to their website, Stripe charges 3.4 percent + S$0.50 (US$0.37) on each transaction. (This includes the fees which Stripe needs to pass on to banks and credit card network schemes like Visa and Mastercard. Custom bulk discounts are available.)

Contrast that against the per transaction fees on the Stellar blockchain (which will be leveraged by SGRR) whereby it only takes US$0.01 to pay for 10,000 transactions currently:

Moreover, the programmability of SGDR allows for event-driven payments, such as a flight insurance payout that gets automatically triggered after a flight delay.

We simply can’t perform the same today, owing to the lack of programmability features in today’s digital money.

For instance, I cannot independently design an application that leverages GrabPay credits to provide automatic flight insurance payouts due to a) the proprietary, closed-loop nature of the GrabPay currency and b) the lack of a programming language native to the currency.

Here’s a list of some possibilities that event-driven payments could help unlock.

How can programmable money help achieve Smart Nation’s goals?

Let us now dive deeper into three initiatives under Smart Nation, which would stand to gain most from leveraging smart, programmable money, namely utilities, autonomous vehicles (AVs), and internet of things (IoT) devices.

Utilities: on-demand billing and rebates

In order to optimize resource usage, Smart Nation intends to incorporate dynamic electricity and water pricing schemes based on the time of day and the amount being consumed by all households.

The collective data gathered from all households will allow for accurate predictive pricing models for both electricity and water.

This will allow an individual consumer to view exactly how much he/she is consuming and spending on a per-second basis for a single particular activity at any point in time. He/she may, for example, choose to program his/her dishwasher to begin its next dishwashing cycle only when electricity and water consumption is at its lowest.

Consumers may be incentivized to reduce their overall consumption patterns through gamification rewards. Them lowering utilities usage would allow them to fall within a certain tier where they would be entitled to rebates, which is instantly paid out. They could even earn money by installing and selling solar panels, which helps to generate electricity back to the grid.

The complex nature of payments required of this initiative would dovetail nicely with the low transaction fees of SGDR (for making and receiving real-time micropayments) as well as its programmability (integrating the predictive pricing models with the logic behind gamification rewards).

Autonomous vehicles (because cars need to pay their bills too)

The revolutionary impact that AVs will have on mankind is likely to surpass that of the previous automobile revolution where cars replaced horses – and the explosion in road imagery data available for analysis is key to that. For a Smart Nation initiative, Singapore has devoted a sizeable amount of resources into this space to ensure that its citizens are able to reap the rewards of deploying AVs en masse. These would include benefits such as:

  1. Less traffic congestion: Machines can be programmed to travel only at optimal speed, with some traffic (e.g goods delivery) being reallocated to be performed at night.
  2. More efficient on-demand vehicle services: Car owners will be able to lease out their AVs to earn money autonomously on their behalf, causing the cost of using such car-sharing services to be even cheaper. This will, in turn, result in fewer cars on the road and less demand for parking spaces.
  3. Fewer accidents: Machines do not get distracted and are programmed to follow road signs and traffic rules.

There are already driverless shuttle buses in Nanyang Technological University, connecting student halls with the main academic areas and ferrying up to 300 passengers each day. / Photo credit: Khalid Baba

AVs will still require to make and take payments of small amounts across regular daily cycles, such as when they pass a road toll, obtain an electrical recharge, enter a workshop for maintenance, or when commuters board them, making it essential for the cost per payment to remain low.

In addition, AVs can be programmed to give commuters the flexibility of deciding the urgency and speed at which they wish to travel. This will allow, for example, someone in a hurry to pay a premium for their ride to afford the right of way. The bonus amount will be shared across commuters occupying other AVs that are willing to travel at a more leisurely pace along the same route.

Such complex, dynamic calculations and payment activities will invariably require a form of smart, programmable money for it to be executed seamlessly.

IoT: data monetization for the masses

We are already living in the IoT era, with everyday things like our smartphones, watches, fitness wearables, televisions, cars, cameras, and home thermostats already connected to the internet.

With technological developments including more powerful microprocessor chips and the impending 5G mobile network to ride on, it won’t be long before even more mundane objects such as refrigerators, drones, street lights, and even pavements become IoT-enables devices as well.

The primary purpose of these IoT devices is to collect data that is to be fed to a predictive model that governs a product’s actions.

This will present an opportunity for consumers to “farm data” for passive income. For example, they can sell anonymized data, which their fitness wearables collect from their daily activities, to a sports equipment manufacturer. The alternative would be for the device manufacturer to own the data collected – be it by consensual or other means – before selling it. Such companies will likely lose out in sales to one that transparently allows the data to be in the users’ control.

A key Smart Nation initiative termed as the “Punggol digital district” strives to foster a high-tech living and working ecosystem, with IoT devices being at the heart of a data economy. Payments for the data will be small and frequent in nature, necessitating for a tool like SGDR to allow for cheap and fast micropayments.

Conclusion

The ultimate objective for Smart Nation is to build a “thriving future for Singapore in the digital era.”

Our location as a hub gave us a strategic advantage historically when it comes to the trading of physical goods. But what will allow Singapore to possess this advantage as we enter the digital age, where digital assets such as data can be traded internationally and freely without physical borders? Why would a company choose to limit itself to purchase training data for its prediction models to just its home country when the market for it is truly global?

The planned initiatives under Smart Nation are definitely a step in the right direction. On the whole, other key factors necessary in order for Singapore to push on would include favorable regulations, a culture of innovation, incentives to encourage early adopters, and financial and human capital.

While having previously acknowledged that central banks entering the fray with central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) are likely to happen, we do not think that this is something that can be implemented within the next two to three years, at least.

Because of the systemic risks that will affect Singapore’s monetary policy, multiple iterations will probably be involved before Project Ubin evolves from being mainly a wholesale banking and securities trading settlement-focused project to one where retail payments also come into play.

The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will need to evaluate the impact of issuing CBDC dollars via the current fractional reserve system – in which a fraction of bank deposits are loaned out in order to expand the economy – to see if doing so will affect the tools they have on hand to tweak their exchange rate policy, which can expand or contract the monetary base – the total amount of currency in circulation.

The alternative – should they go with a full one-to-one collateralization model (i.e. keeping S$1 for each CBDC dollar in circulation) – would, in theory, simplify matters but could have a huge impact on the liquidity of the monetary base, especially if large amounts of CBDC dollars are demanded by, say, the trade finance sector.

(Remember: Banks right now have the ability through fractional reserve banking to issue out more financial capital – for, say, trade finance loans, than the dollar deposits backing it.)

Nonetheless, in the two or three years it takes for the government to decide their approach toward issuing CBDCs, there could already be a whole myriad of experimental case studies from the private sector, which will attract more financial and human capital to the nation.

In light of our transition toward a Smart Nation, perhaps it is time for “money” to mean something else again – one that is programmable, smart, and designed for the smart economies of the future.

Currency converted from Singapore dollar: US$1 = S$1.37.

This article was first published on Medium.

node.title: A stablecoin for the Singapore dollar just launched. Here’s what it’s about
node.content:
Blockchain critics are having a field day right now, with various projects cutting staff as cryptocurrency prices plummet.

But if the past years are any indication, the bear market is probably temporary due to the cyclical nature of cryptocurrency valuations.

What’s more important, though, are the various blockchain projects under development that promise to solve the underlying issues surrounding the technology.

One of the highly touted saviors of the blockchain ecosystem is the so-called stablecoin. As the name implies, stablecoins are cryptocurrencies with stable prices. Each coin is pegged to a corresponding asset – whether it’s the US dollar, the Australian dollar, gold, or anything, really.

There are also stablecoins that stabilize their prices through an algorithm without being attached to an asset.

By being price-stable, it’s hoped that these stablecoins can be used for purposes beyond trading. The hybrid coin is supposed to combine the best features of fiat currencies and the seamlessness of a blockchain network.

See: Stablecoins are close to being a real currency, but not quite

But we still don’t know if stablecoins can live up to the hype. There has been a flowering of stablecoin varieties in the market, but only Tether, which is pegged to the US dollars, has seen significant traction (PDF download). Even so, it seems the only real use cases for stablecoins right now are related to crypto trading.

Against this backdrop comes the launch of the first Singapore dollar-backed stablecoin called SGDR (short for “Singapore dollar rate”). Created by the team behind blockchain startup Rate3, which raised US$15 million in an initial coin offering, SGDR is “a 1:1 Singapore dollar-backed stablecoin, guaranteeing users full redeemability for Singapore dollars on demand,” according to the FAQ.

The currency is only available for accredited or institutional investors at the moment as it’s in closed beta.

With so many stablecoins available to the market, should there be a need for one that’s pegged to the Singapore dollars?

Of course, there is the fact that Singapore is one of a handful of countries that received the top AAA sovereign credit rating by Standard & Poor’s. Essentially, the higher your rating, the less risky it is to invest in your bonds. By extension, the Singapore dollar is the very definition of stability.

Benjamin Ong, who recently joined Rate3 in a product management and strategy role after four years at Mastercard, tells Tech in Asia that there’s more to it than that.

He believes in the potential of stablecoins to power microtransactions for ecommerce, utilities, autonomous vehicles (AVs), and internet of things (IoT) devices.

“AVs will still require to make and take payments of small amounts across regular daily cycles, such as when they pass a road toll, obtain an electrical recharge, enter a workshop for maintenance, or when commuters board them, making it essential for the cost per payment to remain low,” he writes.

Blockchain-enabled microtransactions could also enable a future where ordinary people can easily make passive income. “For example, they can sell anonymized data, which their fitness wearables collect from their daily activities, to a sports equipment manufacturer,” writes Ong.

The current payment infrastructure makes such transactions difficult. Each payment on Stripe, for example, carries a 3.4 percent plus S$0.50 (US$0.37) fee, which can add up quickly. (Of course, Ethereum can suffer the same problem too as its “gas price” has been known to surge when network traffic is high. There are many potential solutions, but that’s a topic for another day.)

Redeeming qualities

Now, even if you accept that stablecoins are somehow magical, do you really need a Singapore dollar-backed version to power microtransactions in Singapore? Blockchain is supposed to be borderless, after all.

Ong brings up the concept of “redeemability,” which he believes is crucial to driving mainstream adoption. Redeemability refers to the ease of converting a cryptocurrency into fiat money.

“Knowing that 1 SGDR always legally entitles you to S$1 in a local bank account helps immensely on this point,” he says. “People are probably hardwired to want to earn and spend in Singapore dollars while engaging with products in Singapore. Not many will own a US bank account, so the need to convert the US dollar stablecoins to fiat US dollars, and then from that to fiat Singapore dollars will involve too much friction for adoption to even occur.”

He adds: “We wouldn’t see mass adoption of WeChat or Alipay for the Chinese yuan among Singaporeans largely because the friction in converting the currency is just too great. The network effects of the local currency for use in the said country is just too strong.”

So stablecoins are an iteration on the blockchain dream, an acknowledgment that fiat currency is here to stay. Rather than trying to disrupt the financial system in its entirety – as early proponents evangelized – a gentle revolution might be the best way forward.

For Rate3, the Singapore dollar is just one of the many assets it plans to tokenize. “After clearing regulations, of course,” Rate3 technical co-founder Davis Gay says.

node.title: Despite Ofo crisis, a growing rival pockets funding
node.content:
While one of the largest bike-share startups teeters on the brink of bankruptcy, a smaller but fast-growing rival has persuaded investors to give it even more cash.

Hellobike today told Tech in Asia that it has “secured billions of yuan in our latest round of fundraising, led by Primavera Capital and Ant Financial,” confirming reports yesterday on Chinese tech media.

Ant Financial, a spin-off from Alibaba, is a return investor.

Photo credit: Hellobike

The exact sum is a secret, though local reports say it’s RMB 4 billion, which works out at US$584 million.

Hellobike’s latest stats:
– In 300 Chinese cities
– Over 20 million daily rides
– 200 million registered users
– No word on active daily/monthly users

Unlike the top two bike apps, Ofo and Mobike, Hellobike has not expanded outside China.

The fresh cash comes a year to the day after it bagged US$500 million in its series D round.

Slowdown

The vote of confidence in Hellobike is arguably a surprise after a year of turmoil for bike-share startups around the world, with China-based Mobike and Ofo pulling out of dozens of cities as they struggled to make money.

Ofo seems the hardest hit, with more than 10 million users demanding deposit refunds as they fear the startup’s collapse, while Ofo’s CEO last week admitted contemplating bankruptcy.

“I told myself – just like I keep telling every Ofo team member – that there is hope in life and that we must withstand great pressure. We must also find ways to overcome big challenges,” wrote Dai Wei in a letter to Ofo staff.

Both Alibaba and Ant Financial have invested in Ofo.

Either Ant Financial knows Hellobike is doing something differently, or the tech giant hasn’t heard the old aphorism that the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results.

node.title: 10 predictions for Southeast Asian tech in 2019
node.content:
We looked back at the 10 predictions we made for 2018 and found that six hit the bull’s eye, three missed the mark, and one remains unclear.

What does 2019 have in store for Southeast Asia?

1. Go-Jek’s traction outside Indonesia will be slow

Since Grab’s acquisition of Uber’s Southeast Asia operations, consumers have been eager to search for more options in the largely monopolized ride-hailing sector.

This is changing. With the pressure to continuously grow, Indonesia’s Go-Jek began expanding into other markets in May 2018. They’ve launched in Vietnam, Singapore, and Thailand, with operations in the Philippines, Malaysia, Myanmar, and Cambodia set for 2019.

Go-Jek as Get in Thailand (left) and Go-Viet in Vietnam (right) / Photo credit: Go-Jek (collage by Tech in Asia)

However, expanding into new markets won’t be easy. We believe that Go-Jek will take it slow (think marathon versus a 100-meter dash). Here are the challenges they may face:

A well-funded incumbent

Grab has been operating in eight markets in Southeast Asia for a long time, and they have enough green ammunition. Will Grab and Go-Jek then start a fierce price war like in the Uber era? Can Go-Jek catch up?

If Go-Jek learned anything from Uber’s (or even Meituan’s) experience in China, they would be wary of the fact that it is pretty hard to catch up with a rich incumbent through burning money.

Distinct differences between Southeast Asia markets

Each market is unique, and with Indonesia strong in Go-Jek’s DNA, adapting to other markets won’t be easy.

Grab grew almost organically across all markets before it became big. Go-Jek, on the other hand, is trying to give their local management greater autonomy.

Moreover, Grab offers the same app across all its markets, while Go-Jek believes in heavily localizing their products. This is an interesting strategy, but whether it can perform well under various shareholder interests and competitive pressures remains to be seen.

Product-market fit

Go-Jek has a very comprehensive product line in Indonesia, but it comes with its own complexities. How it will adapt to new markets quickly and effectively at the product level is also a challenge. Prioritization won’t be easy.

Payment

More on this below, but we believe that the payment market will still be heavily contested in Southeast Asia – without a clear winner to emerge in 2019. How will the Go-Jek story play out in this epic?

Of course, these challenges are not insurmountable, but it will be interesting to see how Go-Jek moves ahead. All these factors put together, Go-Jek needs to be prepared for slow traction in 2019.

2. Payments will remain fragmented

Payments will continue to be a fragmented landscape, with banks, conglomerates, and telcos all sitting on a treasure trove of data and unwilling to give up their lucrative share of the pie.

In Indonesia, the landscape has been constantly evolving with Lippo Group’s Ovo (which works with Grab), Ant Financial, and Emtek’s Dana gaining recent traction in a short time through aggressive marketing.

Dana’s aggressive marketing with huge billboards across Jakarta

Mandiri, Telkomsel, and others also have a stronghold via their e-wallets. Go-Jek’s GoPay, too, is popular because of a strong use case. However, things became interesting when certain partnerships happened: Grab and Tokopedia with Ovo, Bukalapak with Dana, and JD Indonesia with GoPay.

Part of the reason why many companies partnered with existing payments players is the uncertain and stringent license regulations. Indonesia’s central bank, Bank Indonesia (BI), has implemented an effective moratorium of payment license issuance.

However, do note that BI recently issued an e-wallet license to a payment company from China, Bluepay. This fuels speculation that the moratorium will soon be lifted.

That said, in China, before Alipay became dominant, various telcos and other companies tried to build their own payments businesses as well. Though how things played out in China has served a warning to many players in the region, the payments sector will still be fragmented.

Some other markets in Southeast Asia are similar to central banks being quite active in retaining control. Singapore has already bashed third-party payment apps through a unified QR code and has recovered a lot of lost ground (which may not have been lost) for the banks. Thailand’s PromptPay is not as quick as Singapore’s initiative, but it is expected to draw a lot from Singapore’s experience.

3. Ecommerce giants like Tokopedia will move offline more aggressively for growth

The future of ecommerce is offline. The fact that most ecommerce markets in Southeast Asia have captured only less than 4 percent of total retail underscores the staggering potential for growth.

E-tailers across the region see saturation in online marketing channels, infrastructure bottlenecks, and fierce competition for a limited pool of digital consumers (only about half of the population has access to internet in Southeast Asia’s largest economy). All these contribute to a (fast) growth ceiling. To forge ahead quickly, they will need to push for a more aggressive offline strategy.

In Indonesia, for example, Tokopedia is planning to use a large portion of the US$1.1 billion that it recently acquired from Softbank and Alibaba to pursue new retail. Bukalapak has signed up more than 300,000 neighborhood kiosks as partners. And they will continue these efforts to tap into about 90 percent of the retail market that’s still outside the ecommerce platform.

Elsewhere too, retailers are realizing that strategic brick-and-mortar stores and other offline channels are necessary to scale operations across the region.

4. More money will go into revamping the region’s logistics network

Logistics in Southeast Asia has only started to accelerate in recent years. And with the rise of ecommerce, the pain points are becoming obvious, leaving a large room for improvement.

With the opportunity ripe and lucrative, it is not difficult to predict that many players will continue to eye the Southeast Asian market in the near future.

Alibaba has been making inroads into the logistics sector in the region by investing in various markets. It built its first logistics hub in Kuala Lumpur, it invested in SingPost, and it is now targeting to complete an ecommerce and logistics hub in Thailand in 2019.

In 2017, JD.com has increased its investment in logistics in Southeast Asia. J&T Express’ achievements in Indonesia have also been widely known, expanding to many places outside Indonesia in 2018.

Ecommerce delivery is only a small part of the overall logistics market, with a lot of opportunities untapped and inefficiencies unresolved. We see more capital and startups moving into the field in 2019.

5. Chinese cross-border ecommerce competition will intensify

The cross-border ecommerce market in Southeast Asia still faces significant challenges. To put things into perspective, the combined orders to this region for cross-border sellers add up to a tiny percentage of what they could do on Amazon alone.

In 2017, giants such as Shopee and Lazada have been doing well in educating the market. Complicated customs clearance has become more transparent and regulations have become more comprehensible. Customs clearance agents have also become more professional and mature.

This is the same forecast we made for 2018. However, infrastructure challenges such as payments, language, and localization made development in this sector slower than predicted.

But with the continued saturation of the European and American markets and some external factors (including a series of restrictions imposed by Amazon’s most recent sellers in 2018), more cross-border sellers will focus their attention on Southeast Asia instead.

Let’s not forget that the region is collectively richer than India and much bigger than Saudi Arabia, both seeing great Chinese cross-border incursion in 2018.

6. It will be survival of the fittest, not the fastest, in fintech

We predicted that the payday loan bubble in Southeast Asia would burst in 2018, with many outside companies coming into the region to make quick profits.

Nonetheless, the potential of fintech in the region is evident. For example, there is a US$73 billion loan gap in Indonesia, according to research. It is predicted that at the end of 2018 fintech lending will fill this gap with a meager estimated amount of US$1.3 billion. This means that 98 percent still remains unfulfilled. It’s easy to see why so many foreign players are salivating at the prospects.

However, regulators have been cracking their whips, which saw a number of businesses stripped of their registration. Over 400 illegal P2P lenders have been identified between January and October 2018. Regulators have also been paying heed to the outcry of thousands of customers who complained against aggressive debt practices.

But this does not mean that the doors are closed for Indonesia’s P2P lending industry. On the contrary, strict supervision is conducive to the industry’s healthy development. Those who plan to stay in the game for a long time don’t want the market disrupted by reckless players.

2019 is when the fittest – not the fastest – will survive. It is not enough to move fast, play aggressive, and make quick money. Instead, players need to build their core risk control capabilities while adapting to the ever-changing regulatory environment.

We think many of the current top players will fall on the way forward in 2019.

7. Singapore will find a better niche as many AI and robo-advisory startups fail

In order to find new economic growth areas, Singapore launched the National Artificial Intelligence Program in 2017. Major universities have also set up research centers with AI-related scholarships.

Bolstered by the government’s heavy investments in grants for AI, Singapore have seen myriads of AI and robo-advisory startups mushroom over the last few years. Many startups have received initial rounds of investments, but they were not able to deliver on productive, tangible outcomes. Moreover, the market outlook cannot support further growth.

In this regard, the Singapore government is actually very self-aware. After all, Singapore’s core competitiveness is not about scale (the core of many AI fields is the size of data engineers and data) but about continuing to lead in the fields of systems and environment.

It is expected that in 2019 Singapore will find a more suitable niche for local startups – but it won’t be AI.

8. Nobody will talk about series B crunch anymore

VCs and other investors from the US, Japan, and China all share a keen interest in Southeast Asia’s tech market and growing consumption. However, despite meeting up and taking part in various forums and platforms, their interactions haven’t been that in-depth. Oftentimes, information is not effectively communicated between various groups.

We see things changing in 2019. With the capital environment becoming colder in other regions, Southeast Asia will become a warm melting pot due to the inflow and integration of diverse capital.

9. Financial advisory for VC investments as an industry will gain traction

In the past few years, there weren’t that many good startups in the region. Oftentimes, as an investor, you just needed to do a round of the region’s capitals to meet all the potential investment targets.

But now, the situation has changed. Some unicorn executives have decided to start their own businesses. And the obvious opportunities have been taken – VCs have to spend more time judging startups from unfamiliar fields. Also, as mentioned above, the presence of VCs from different backgrounds makes scanning the market and decision making more challenging.

Therefore, the time is ripe for the development of an intermediary industry, that is financial advisory or FA. Although there are already many FAs active in the region, very few can really help solve the issue of information asymmetry in investing and assist in making judgments.

In 2019, we believe that some good boutique FAs will start emerging in this area.

10. E-scooters will fail to take off in the region

E-scooters have begun ramping up their presence in Southeast Asia. Uber-backed Lime has launched a pilot fleet in Singapore. Neuron Mobility snagged US$3.7 million to expand to Bangkok and Chiang Mai. Singapore-based Beam raised US$6.4 million in seed funding to launch e-scooters in Singapore and Asia.

Lime has begun rolling out its e-scooters in Singapore via a partnership with property developer Ascendas-Singbridge. / Photo credit: Zhaki Abdullah

However, the development of this industry won’t be smooth in 2019.

Singapore may be the most conducive market for e-scooters in the region, but the country’s Land and Transport Authority (LTA) has been quite strict, armed with its experience regulating the bike-sharing industry.

Singapore’s LTA slaps notice on scores of e-scooters across the country. / Photo credit: LTA Newsroom

A Beam scooter impounded in Bugis, Singapore / Photo credit: LTA Newsroom

Some scooters found outside permitted areas were impounded:

And the strict licensing imposes limitations on maximum fleet size and compels operators to enforce responsible parking practices. Operators can be fined huge sums of money for violation – and we saw how that turned out for Ofo. As a result, Neuron Mobility had to downsize its fleet and is now awaiting changes in regulations, which will take a few more months.

While this has slowed down the development of e-scooter startups in Singapore, we don’t expect things to be rosy in other markets either. With cheaper alternatives like motorbike taxis available in emerging markets like Indonesia and Vietnam, is there even a demand that e-scooters need to fulfill?

Australia and New Zealand are more viable markets for e-scooter companies.

This article was first published on The Low Down.

node.title: GrabJobs grabs funding to grow jobs portal for retail, restaurants
node.content:
Singapore-based startup GrabJobs has raised funding, it revealed today, as expansion of its jobs portal continues, with users dotted across Singapore, Philippines, Myanmar, and Thailand.

GrabJobs now has an extra US$681,000 in seed funding, bringing its total raised so far to US$1.8 million.

The fledgling portal focuses on people seeking jobs in the retail and restaurant sectors, which generally struggle to hold onto staff for long periods.

Photo credit: kyryll ushakov / Unsplash

“The highest number of employers and job seekers are in Singapore and the Philippines. We are also currently running pilots in Malaysia, Indonesia, South Africa, and India,” a GrabJobs representative tells Tech in Asia.

Its job seekers post 50,000 applications per month via its app. No data on active users is available.

GrabJobs is also installing kiosks – basically tablets on a stand – in places where youngsters who typically go into retail and restaurant positions hang out:

Photo credit: GrabJobs

So far, GrabJobs has put kiosks in establishments run by Singapore restaurant firm Spa Esprit Group, and is in discussions with multiple colleges to put them on campus.

Started in 2015, the startup now has 25 employees across its Singapore HQ plus offices in the Philippines and Myanmar.

The startup makes money from recruiters, who have the option to purchase monthly subscriptions for full access to the service or buy credits to shortlist applicants individually.

Converted from Singapore dollars. Rate: US$1 = S$1.36.

node.title: 5 digital marketing channels that work best in Indonesia
node.content:
This article is brought to you by Studios, Tech in Asia’s new advertising arm which provides integrated media, marketing, events, and design solutions to help brands expand their reach in the tech ecosystem. Get in touch with us at studios[at]techinasia[dot]com for your tailored business solutions.

You can also sign up for Studios’ bi-weekly newsletter to have resources on marketing, sales, events and the latest tech updates delivered straight to your inbox.

With a population of more than 263 million people, Indonesia holds tremendous potential for local startups and foreign enterprises looking to break into the market.

Social media and internet usage rates are rising fast, with one survey recording 143.26 million active internet users in 2017 – a 7.9 percent increase from the previous year. Along with a growing middle-and-affluent-consumer class, the country is dominated by young people who are tech-savvy and eager to spend their money on new products and services.

These results are consistent with the findings of a 2017 study, which showed that Indonesia is now one of the world’s fastest growing mobile commerce markets.

The challenges of diversity

Yet Indonesia also presents unique stumbling blocks for business owners and marketers.

For starters, the country’s archipelagic structure means that 265 million people are scattered across 17,500 islands, each one with different tastes and preferences. This level of diversity means that marketing tactics that work in the capital city of Jakarta, for example, may not necessarily work in another urban center like Surabaya.

In fact, McKinsey & Company found that consumer behavior in Surabaya was more likely to be influenced by branding and image compared to the consumer behavior in Jakarta. Consumers in Surabaya are also reportedly twice as likely than consumers in Jakarta to seek recommendations from family and friends before making purchase decisions, particularly when it comes to fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG).

One thing for sure is that more Indonesians are going digital. Growth is especially pronounced in the smartphone space, with 47 percent of the total population regularly accessing the Internet on some kind of mobile device.

Of that number, 80 percent use their mobile devices to look for information about products and services.

Top digital marketing platforms in Indonesia

But where exactly do Indonesian buyers go online?

According to Hootsuite’s We Are Social Report for 2018, the most active social media platforms in Indonesia are YouTube, Facebook, WhatsApp, Instagram, and LINE.

We’ll take a look at how businesses are using each social network to reach out to customers.

1. YouTube

According to a 2017 survey commissioned by market research firm Jakpat, 54 percent of Indonesians use YouTube to watch tutorial video content.

Source: eMarketer

These findings are consistent with Google’s research, which found that in Southeast Asian countries like Thailand and Indonesia, being on YouTube has become a social activity that involves shared interests, such as watching makeup tutorials. Google calls these people who spend more than 10 hours a week on the platform “YouTube Enthusiasts”.

Learn from the locals: Among local brands, Tokopedia has the largest audience on YouTube, with over 415 million views as of this writing. The company uses YouTube to publish online classes alongside TV commercials and feature stories about notable ecommerce sellers, among others.

Why does this matter? Those same “YouTube Enthusiasts” are also frequent and high ecommerce spenders. If you’re an online retailer, how-to videos about featured products could be the tool that turns a YouTube Enthusiast into a customer.

2. Facebook

With more than 130 million active users in 2018, Facebook penetration in Indonesia is growing rapidly, up by 23 percent from the previous year. Brands in the FMCG and ecommerce industries take the lion’s share of Facebook engagement.

Of the platforms on this list, Facebook is unique for seeing the most frequent daily use among Indonesians. The platform also serves as a social marketplace and launchpad for buyers in the country, 40 percent of whom use Facebook to look for product information and recommendations.

The latter is especially important, as 31 percent of Indonesian Facebook users make a purchase decision based on recommendations. These reviews generate even more discussions as consumers use Facebook to share about their shopping experience and purchase.

Learn from the locals: Insights from Social Bakers reveal that ecommerce brands like Sale Stock use Facebook to engage millions of social media followers, keeping them abreast of new products, promotions, and other announcements.

The fact that Sale Stock’s leading goods are beauty products just so happens to align with Facebook’s findings, which show 56 percent of Indonesian beauty shoppers look for reviews and 33 percent make more purchases on mobile.

Bottom line? If you’re an online retailer, it would be in your best interest to be active on Facebook, engage users, and encourage reviews.

3. WhatsApp

Hootsuite’s We Are Social report shows that WhatsApp outranks Facebook and Facebook Messenger apps in terms of monthly active users in Indonesia.

Source: Hootsuite

After the instant messaging service released its official WhatsApp Business app in January last year, we can expect to see more local businesses using the platform to communicate with customers. In addition, with integration into Facebook and Instagram, social media users can easily send inquiries to companies through WhatsApp, allowing marketers to build a list of high-potential leads.

For now, however, the mobile app is available only on Android and in Indonesia, Italy, Mexico, the United Kingdom, and the United States, geared towards helping smaller businesses in establishing an official presence on the WhatsApp social network. Still, Indonesian companies are already reaping its rewards.

Learn from the locals: In just a year, we’ve seen brands take advantage of this service, with Sale Stock using WhatsApp Business to engage customers and respond to their queries more efficiently, generating inbound traffic to its ecommerce site.

Source: Facebook Business

The company did this by using the WhatsApp Business API to engage Indonesian customers at three stages in the customer’s journey:

  1. Generate awareness by announcing new products and promotions
  2. Make personalized recommendations to customers based on the products they viewed
  3. Send notifications (e.g. order confirmation, shipping updates) to customers after they place an order

This proves that WhatsApp isn’t just an instant messaging service; when used effectively, it can be a lead generation as well as a customer acquisition and retention tool.

4. Instagram

Instagram is huge in Indonesia. In fact, it’s the fourth leading country in terms of monthly active users (behind the United States, India, and Brazil).

Insights from parent company Facebook also prove Instagram’s influence on shopping behavior, particularly during the holidays, with 86 percent of holiday consumers in Indonesia using the app for shopping ideas.

Instagram Stories has also taken off in the Indonesian market. Among those surveyed in the country, 62 percent use Stories to browse content, while only 38 percent use the regular Instagram feed.

The reason? Indonesians are drawn to Instagram Stories’ authentic and ephemeral nature, which lets them be “real” in their communications with friends and family.

Learn from the locals: This may explain why Samsung’s Indonesia team succeeded in using Instagram Stories to launch the Galaxy A 2017 series and reinforce its position in the mid-range smartphone space. Because mid-range phones are targeted primarily towards younger device users, Samsung Indonesia saw Instagram Stories as the ideal immersive ad platform to appeal to tech-savvy millennials.

Source: Samsung Indonesia

The campaign’s creative idea focused on young people using the Samsung A7 as they went about their daily lives, highlighting features such as water resistance and low-light camera performance using texts and emoji stickers. Above all else, the mission was to create video ads that seamlessly fit with the format and appeal of Instagram Stories.

For businesses looking to advertise on Instagram Stories, you need to tailor your content to the platform and the attitudes of the local audience using it instead of forcing things the other way around.

5. LINE

In June this year, Japanese instant messaging app LINE launched LINE Today, a dedicated news platform for the Indonesian market.

In a country where 90 million people actively use the service – placing it next to Taiwan and Thailand as the app’s top three overseas markets – the move was part of LINE’s strategic effort to cultivate brand loyalty and diversify its services.

Source: LINE

Learn from the locals: As the messaging app sets its sights on becoming Indonesia’s number one smart portal, the company is looking to monetize channels like its Line Business Contact service. Currently, local companies such as Go-Jek and Sale Stock are using the service to communicate with LINE users and offer features such as real-time monitoring of motorbike taxi drivers (for Go-Jek) and AR changing rooms (for Sale Stock).

Businesses looking to enter the Indonesian market need to consider LINE’s popularity and growing engagement rates, and look at ways to integrate the messaging app into their lead generation, customer relationship management, and customer retention strategies. They can also tap into LINE Today as a channel for promoting sponsored content through different online publications.

Traditional media still dominant in Indonesia

While digital and social media networks are on the rise in Indonesia, it’s worth noting that TV continues to the be the most dominant platform in the country, with 95 percent of adults actively using it.

In fact, the most popular Indonesian channels on YouTube in terms of total views are the official online extensions of TV news and music stations like RCTI, Indosiar, and Trans TV, among others. PwC predicts that television will continue to be the main advertising medium in Indonesia until 2021, accounting for a 53.8 percent market share in 2017 – up by 0.2 percent from 2016.

With the country having one of the slowest Internet speeds in the Asia-Pacific region (average of 9.73 mbps), overseas companies from developed countries would be advised to reconsider using bandwidth-heavy content, such as 4K video or interactive sites.

Marketing trends to look forward to

If 2018 was the year for ephemeral content (e.g. Instagram Stories, Facebook Messenger Day, and Snapchat Stories) in Indonesia, what can business owners and marketers look forward to in 2019?

We can expect ephemeral content to continue to gain popularity, with more businesses using the format and connecting Instagram or Snapchat Stories directly to their ecommerce sites.

We may also see an upsurge in gamified marketing, what with Hago, a social gaming app, drawing 30 million downloads in Indonesia alone this year. The number of Indonesian mobile game players is also expected to reach 100 million players in 2019 or 2020, presenting an advertising opportunity for local businesses.

WhatsApp and LINE’s continued innovations in instant messaging for the Indonesian market may also point to a greater global trend. According to Hootsuite chief marketing officer Penny Wilson, “The savviest brands will migrate to messaging apps to meet their customers when and where they want to be served.”

Whether it’s TV or the Internet, Indonesia’s consumers expect brands to meet them where they are, in the way they want. Businesses should adjust accordingly, or risk losing potential customers altogether.

node.title: Didi is bidding to become a fintech giant
node.content:
China’s top ride-hailing app today expanded its repertoire by selling financial services to its 550 million users.

Didi this morning announced the rollout of personal insurance, wealth management, mutual protection, crowdfunding products for critical illnesses, car loans, and other forms of credit services, all available within its app.

In a statement, Didi said its health insurance product “breaks down annual critical illness insurance to lower the entry barrier for gig economy workers and broaden the scope of protection for more families.”

The US$56 billion startup last year made some financial services available to its drivers, but today’s move expands its fintech ambitions to everyone across China.

The nationwide launch comes four months after Didi vowed to plough US$1 billion into building up its financial services wing.

The transport app’s finance products go up against Alibaba spin-off Alipay, Tencent’s WeChat, as well as a number of the nation’s top banks and insurers.
